body:
I guess something like the following will also fail, if I understand the issue correctly:

`rclone lsd "Crypt_Remote:REDACTED/HDD (Y:)"`
`rclone copy "Crypt_Remote:REDACTED/HDD (Y:)/quarentine" .`

No, those two don't fail. They would if they would make rclone create a file/folder with the `:` in the name. I can list and I can copy files from the remote because rclone doesn't create the `HDD (Y:)` folder to download/list files. All what it fails in this issue is the part where rclone tries to create the directory `HDD (Y:)` inside the `REDACTED` dir because Windows doesn't acccept `:` in paths.

OK.. I tested with another backend, and there are some differences regarding what rclone treats as legal characters for each backend. And I'm struggling a bit to grasp the exact "flow" here, and e.g. if this is something that should have been prevented by the backend encoding..

Quick questions, just to be sure:
You have a dir with name `HDD (Y:)` in your remote? How did you create it, I mean using rclone, and from Windows, or some other way?

I did another attempt at reproducing, and think I got closer to do so. Tried a small change in cache path handling that possibly fixes it. Are you willing to run a quick test with a beta build from my fork: https://github.com/albertony/rclone/releases/tag/v1.56.0-cache-ospath-01 ?

>
>
> Quick questions, just to be sure:
> You have a dir with name `HDD (Y:)` in your remote? How did you create it, I mean using rclone, and from Windows, or some other way?

Yes. My remote is:

```
REDACTED
		/ HDD (Y:)
					/ quarentine
```

The directory was created using rclone on Windows by using something like:

`rclone copy Y:\ "Crypt_Remote:REDACTED\HDD (Y:)"`

The directory containing the `:` char doesn't exist on the local path, it was created when trasferring the files from local to remote.  
  

>
> 
> I did another attempt at reproducing, and think I got closer to do so. Tried a small change in cache path handling that possibly fixes it. Are you willing to run a quick test with a beta build from my fork: [albertony/rclone@`v1.56.0-cache-ospath-01` (release)](https://github.com/albertony/rclone/releases/tag/v1.56.0-cache-ospath-01) ?

Just tried your build and the mount works well now, I have tried opening some files and it went all well and I got nothing in the logs anymore. Thanks for looking into this.

>The directory was created using rclone on Windows by using something like:

I see, thanks for explaining (again).

> Just tried your build and the mount works well now, I have tried opening some files and it went all well and I got nothing in the logs anymore. 

Thats great, thanks for testing! There might be more to it before a final fix, as this was sort of a quick "proof of consept", but I will create a pull request and get to the bottom of it there.

issue.title: vfs: ensure names used in cache path are legal on current os

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### What is the purpose of this change?

As described in the issue: You can have a dir with `:` in the name in a remote. When mounting this with cache on Windows, the current cache code did not handle such characters that are invalid in paths, and it tried (without luck) to create a dir within the cache location containing the `:`.

With this change: When cache builds the path to be used within the local file cache for a given remote path, it now relies on `FromStandardPath`, with an encoder that properly handle characters not valid in paths on current os.

This is similar to what the local backend does: So refactored the default encoder from the local backend into lib/encoder as `OS` encoder, to re-use it.

An early version was confirmed to fix the linked issue, but I'm still a bit uncertain if this is the correct/best way to handle it...

#### Was the change discussed in an issue or in the forum before?

Fixes #5360

#### Checklist

- [X] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-a-pull-request).
- [ ] I have added tests for all changes in this PR if appropriate.
- [ ] I have added documentation for the changes if appropriate.
- [X] All commit messages are in [house style](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit-messages).
- [x] I'm done, this Pull Request is ready for review :-)

body: Sorry this fell off my radar for the release. I'll follow up on the PR.
